comments.commentBody:
Have you looked at the latest in police technology?

It's 'way too late for any resistance, sorry.

One out of every two Americans is poor, unemployed or underemployed - if things don't improve, hurtful language will be the least of the bankers worries.

If things continue getting worse, and the out look is overwhelming that they will, then protests will, eventually, at some point become physical. The mob may call for the heads of the politicians, or the lobbyist, or the bankers or the CEOs or the Wealthy or some combination there of. My guess is, giving the current rhetoric, they'd start with the top 0.01% and begin to work their way down.

One wonders, then, how the rich will react to the calls for Guillotines.

When one's world is going swimmingly, one wonders how and why anyone would be vocal about changing things. When the melt down was occuring in the fall of 2008, the wealthy were concerned. Now, from their perspective, everything's fine, so why the rough language. They idea that one out of every two Americans is suffering just doesn't register when you are making more money than ever. History shows that the rich are the last to sweat, but they sweat with their blood.

Let's hope it doesn't come to that. Not all the elite's are idiots. In the past, for every Henry Potter consumed with his own personal greed, there's a Sam Wainwright who knows how to step forward and do the right thing. America the Bedford Falls or America the Pottersville? What will it be?

Brilliant and hilarious work, Mr. Tanier...much good has come from your devotion to these boids ...but I'd like to quibble with paragraph 3: the Eagles playoff path requires 4 specific game results (Eagles over 'boys, Jets over Giants, Giants over 'boys, Eagles over 'skins)...if each of these results has a 50% probability (and I know they don't exactly, but the odd 60-40 instead doesn't change the following calculation in any meaningful way), then the probability of all 4 occurring is 50% x 50% x 50% x 50%  = ~6%...very different from the impression that paragraph 3 leaves, which is that the Eagles making the playoffs is no longer far-fetched...yes it is...or perhaps 'e's just restin'...remarkable bird, the Norwegian Blue...beautiful plumage...

No that we have left the world will witness firsthand the hatred between Sunni and Shitte. Iraq is destined to fall into a power struggle between Islamic forces unfriendly to the U.S. and friends with Iran. Or a regional power of its own with internal strife going on for decades. We left it better than we found it, the only problem is no person ever asked the question. How many Iraqi's must die to free Iraq. The answer is over one million died. A high price to pay to jump from the frying pan to the fire. Naively  George W Bush said God told him it was his place to free the Iraqi people. I think it was Dick Cheney playing God and Bush buying it.

If you want out of control, loud, drunken fans just go down the road to Philadelphia. Remember when you celebrated your first TD? There was someone there who said, "Act like you've been there before." and that made a lot of sense back then when folks were much more modest about themselves. The way the Giants organization has run their shop reflects that noblesse oblige´ kind of thing. Naturally their fans would celebrate more quietly. But have you been to the stadium? The bottom third has been supplanted with these luxury clubs, and suites and boxes. I've been following the Giants since the 1970 season. All three Super Bowls have happened on my watch. Some teams still haven't gotten to a Super Bowl. What's frustrating right now is that they could be better; they are inconsistent.

Until this season it looked like the Niners wasted a number one pick on QB Alex Smith, but now it looks like rookie coach Jim Harbaugh has completely turned around a team that finished 6-10 last year to 11-3 so far. Do you think he has a good shot at winning coach of the year?
Dude, you can write! Thanks for the Master Class. As old masters like George Vecsey pass the torch, it is good to see new talent like Mike Tanier continue to raise the bar.

At last some common sense. The idea that competition among insurers will somehow lower health care costs is nonsense as is the idea the purchase of health is subject to market forces like buying a TV.

HTTP://www.quinnscommentary.com

Tunnel vision. What Medicare needs is expansion, not contraction. Let every working person enroll in Medicare so we can have a one-payer system and end the mind-boggling mess of private insurers with ever-increasing premiums fired by hospitals soaking the insured to pay for the uninsured. Will that mean close supervision by government over which services get paid for and which don't?
Yes, it will. Then everything will be on the table. What we have now is a no-win situation.
A necessary component of the solution is a national conversation about determining appropriate medical treatment at the end of life.

There is unlimited demand for a free good,

Why should society spend more for your healthcare than you are willing to? People need to be "insured" against unanticipated loss not regular expenses. We need to get people back to the idea that they are responsible for themselves, insurance is for the unanticipated, needing healthcare is not unanticipated.
corporations are for profit nothing wrong with that.

So once again propaganda wins out over truth or logic.

So let's cap costs at 1 % over GDP growth. I am sure a whole new batch of doctor wanna-bes will rush right out, spend the 100's of thousands of dollars on education and greuling residency knowing that they cannot make more than GDP ROG 1%.

Yet if they instead decided to push papers as a government employee or do menial work as a union member - then there are no limits on what they can demand or earn.

Gimme a break
"Someone has to play God" or not. People can pay for their own costs, if people cannot pay then society cannot either.
I do not see any evidence that this works in England. Shoddy medical care is what you get, and rationing by age. Please do not get sick if you are 62 or older...

This argument is deeply flawed. Bundling of care is nothing more than re-branded capitation. It turns primary care providers into insurers, and creates a huge conflict of interest between providers and patients.

The writer is concerned about insurance companies only wanting healthy patients. If you turn physicians into insurers, then you will get the same problem. Why should I, a Family Physician, keep a non-compliant diabetic in my practice? And why should I also be held financially accountable for the exaggerated health care costs generated by this patient.

During the health care debate 2 years ago, the Dartmouth Atlas Project was briefly in the spotlight. Their conclusion is that if a health care resource exists, if will be used. Both bundling of care and premium support focus solely on demand for health care services. By ignoring the excessive supply of some health care services, and the shortages in others, these notions are doomed from the start.

I practice in a rural area where some health care resources are rationed in practice. It is not the end of the world. An article quoting the now former director of the CMS said 20-25% of health care spending is unnecessary care. We need to limit the supply of these excessive and unnecessary resources if we want to reign in health care spending.

Am I advocating for rationing? Yes. When 44 million American's don't have health insurance, we are already rationing care. We need to ration care more sensibly.

Food is a right but I am not paying your restaurant bill. If you cannot feed yourself you can go to a soup kitchen or a food pantry and take charity. We will only contain health costs when people see and pay the cost for is and we band together for the unanticipated.

Medicare is not the healthcare coverage that working people expect in our old age. It is so limited that many are forced into Medicaid. We have to distinguish health care cost from health care; most of the discussions are about the cost of health care not actually about keeping hose eligible for Medicare healthy.

Most of us who pay into the Medicare system would pay more if the coverage for our long-term health care needs were being covered. But what is happening: we are relying on a system of health care coverage through Medicare which is sadly inadequate, and by the time we figure out the inadequacy we are hit by some catastrophic illness or major medical incident requiring us to pay more than if we had bought private insurance or the government’s required contribution to Medicare were higher.

The consequences: the leap from Medicare to Medicaid which is very costly to Medicare eligible recipients.

There are a few things that the analysis in this article does not take into account:
1) The huge amount of money spent on (futile, painful) end of life care. Our system is such that the patient can say "do everything" and the hospital must, regardless of whether they will ever be paid and regardless if whether there is an chance of achieving a good outcome
2) The large proportion of health care dollars spent by a relatively few "frequent" flyers - see the work of the group at Cooper Medical center in Camden NJ for example. At major academic medical center, many of the patients are well known by the staff as they are in the hospital so frequently. It is all too frequent that a patient with congestive heart failure smokes crack, ends up in the hospital for a week and then uses crack again within a week of discharge and ends up in the hospital again. It is neither feasible nor should be within the purview of the physician to have to deal with the self-destructive behaviors of this patient population that, while relatively small in number, utilizes an outsized share of health care resources. Nor is it appropriate to punish the healthcare providers for the behavior of this sort of patient - which is exactly what Dr. Emmanuel proposes.
One might suggest that Dr. Emmanuel spend a few weeks taking care of patients at UPenn and see what the real world looks like to physicians

This article is correct. So far, there is no political leadership to address the four critical areas which determine the %GDP we spend on health care: costs of medical tests and procedures, unnecessary medical tests, profit-taking middlemen, and end-of-life care. Everything that has been done so far (e.g. "Obamacare") is just a shell game, and overall health care spending is continuing to increase.
Obvious ways to address this situation include reimbursing health care workers according to time not procedure (like attorneys and many other educated professionals); changing profit incentives for ordering tests which may not be clinically necessary; moving to a single-payer system; and reducing the use of expensive interventions in terminal patients when there is little likelihood of a significant clinical impact.

The USA spends about twice as much on health care than most European countries without a significant improvement in outcome. 50% of the cost does nothing to improve our health..... or life span. Each attempt to rationally lower costs meets massive outcries from patients ........ e.g. mammograms and PSA testing. No doubt the medical specialists and hospitals also have a vested interest in these procedures. To quote Bruna above:

"The key to reducing costs is not just all the other "evil" players, it's us. .... The key to affordable Medicare (and other health care) has to come down to some limits on open access to everything. The biggest problem is not the nasty insurers or drug companies, it's us.

In our society most of the players (patients, doctors, hospitals, suppliers, insurance companies, etc.) are concerned only with me, me, me, me..... There must be limits placed on the dollars spent on medical care which do not cost effectively improve our health or lifespan. Perhaps all citizens should be entitled to free Type A vouchers to support 'necessary' care which has been proven to work and be cost effective in other countries. Type B vouchers could then be purchased 'out of pocket' (by individuals or employers) for health care which is less cost effective, not effective at all, or perhaps worse.

If you feel that you need an MRI 'right now' to make you feel less anxious and sleep better, then go for it ............ on your own dime !

I am not saying the expenses from the lawsuits are that great, it's the doctors over-testing and over-treating in order to avoid lawsuits that causes the expense.

Of course, many serious things are caught this way, and people's lives are saved. But it does cost a lot of money.
60 billion in fraud!  Perhaps there are easier targets than doctors.

The blind fools who wish to tear the remainder of our scant social safety net to shreds are genuinely cruel and short-sighted.

And apparently, all wealthy enough to go it alone - through cancer, Alzheimers, renal failure - whatever may come.

We need to be shoring Medicare up and expanding it, not throwing the aged and ill to the tender mercies of private insurers.

Because, we see how well *that* works for those of us under 65.

Not really. The best financial incentives and disincentives would be around a persons responsibility for their own health. I am well aware that many health issues are genetic, or hereditary or just plain accidental; but the truth is that the most widespread and costly are a result of choice, behavior, and more than anything, lack of education. Give incentives for good behavior and penalties for bad behavior and costs will at least reflect the truth.

Miss Independent... ummm.. "Doctors don't charge anything." Really? Is this kind of like "factory workers don't charge anything - they just punch a timeclock every day?" It's not required that you carry a cash register around with you in order to charge for your work. And what is with the med school arguments - that they *have* to be paid handsomely so that they may pay off their loans. Is this some kind of bizarre charity for the soon-to-be-affluent that I'm participating in when I go to the doctor? Practically everyone that goes into higher education these days incurs major debt, very often without nearly the future earning potential of MDs, not to mention the job security.
No one is complaining about the docs who toil away in the ED of a grimy county hospital in the middle of the night. The waste comes from the docs who order MRI after MRI w/o any concrete reason, who choose brand names over generics 'cause that's how they roll (or because they simply can't be bothered to educate their patients), who 'feed the beast' by referring their patients to the same specialists they play squash with on the weekends, who drag their patients in for more follow-up visits than necessary, who always order the full panel when they only need a specific result, who perform surgeries that are no better than non-invasive therapy, on and on. That's fee for service. There's no need to sugar coat it. It's certainly not the only problem w. US healthcare, but it is a major one.
